content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose strategy B{B}. Here's my reasoning:

1. In this game, both players are better off cooperating (i.e., choosing the same option), as they get higher payoffs when they do so. Choosing R results in a higher payoff for the other player, but a lower payoff for me, while choosing B results in a lower payoff for the other player but a slightly higher payoff for me.

2. Since I don't know what strategy the other player will choose, it's reasonable to assume that they are also trying to maximize their own payoffs, just like me. This means that if I choose R, there is a good chance that they will choose B, and I will end up with 0$. On the other hand, if I choose B, there is still a chance (about 1/2) that they will also choose B, and I will get 20$ per round.

3. Over the course of 75 rounds, the expected payoff for choosing R is: (45 * P(both R)) + (0 * P(R & B)) = 45P(both R)
   The expected payoff for choosing B is: (20 * P(both B)) + (40 * P(R & B)) = 20P(both B) + 40(1 - P(both R))

4. Since both players are rational, we can assume that they will choose the strategy that results in a higher expected payoff. If my opponent chooses R, I should choose B to maximize my payoffs, and vice versa.

5. Given these assumptions, it seems more likely that my opponent will also choose B, since choosing B results in a lower but still positive payoff for them, while choosing R could result in 0$. Therefore, I would choose strategy B{B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

Since my opponent chose R in the previous round, I would choose B again in this round. My reasoning is that if I had chosen R, my opponent would have gotten 45$ and I would have received 0$. However, by choosing B, I still get a positive payoff of 20$, while there is a chance (about 1/2) that my opponent will now choose B as well, resulting in both of us earning 20$ per round. Over the course of many rounds, this strategy is likely to result in higher overall earnings compared to always choosing R against an opponent who consistently chooses R. Therefore, I would choose strategy B{B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

Since both me and my opponent chose B in the previous round, I would choose strategy R{R} in this round. My reasoning is that by always choosing the same strategy as my opponent (i.e., cooperating), we will both consistently earn a payoff of 20$ per round. However, if I continue to choose B and my opponent switches to R, I would receive 0$ while my opponent receives 45$. Therefore, by occasionally switching strategies (choosing R instead of B when my opponent chooses B), I can potentially maximize my earnings in the long run. This strategy is known as a "tit-for-tat" strategy, where you cooperate at first but retaliate if your opponent defects. However, since we don't know whether my opponent will switch strategies or not, it may be better to simply stick with the cooperative strategy for now and see how things develop over time. Therefore, I would choose strategy R{R}.

Furthermore, since we are both rational players trying to maximize our earnings, it's reasonable to assume that my opponent will continue to choose R as well, given the higher payoff. Therefore, I would choose strategy R{R}.
